Explore data

Contents

  • variables - Listing variables
  • meta - Exploring meta data
  • Other methods to explore data
  • Pandas dataframe

Explore data#

Once our data is loaded, we can explore what variables it has and the meta data for the variables. We assume that the data has been loaded into a variable called dataset. For more information on the API endpoints used in these examples, refer to the Tally API documentation.

variables - Listing variables#

Use the variables method to get a list of variables. It returns a dictionary with the keys keys single, delimited set, array, int, float, string, date. These all have a list of strings that are the names of variables.

dataset.variables()

{'single': ['gender',
  'locality',
  'ethnicity',
  'religion',
  'q1',
  'q2__1',
  'q2__2',
  'q2__3',
  'q2__4',
  'q2__5',
  'q2__6',
  'q2__97',
  'q2__98',

  'q3__7',
  'q3__8',

meta - Exploring meta data#

Use the meta method to explore answer codes and labels.

>>> dataset.meta('q1')
codes texts missing
1 1 CBD (central business district) None
2 2 Urban None
3 3 Suburban None
4 4 Rural None
5 5 Remote None

Other methods to explore data#

Other methods to explore the data include get_variable_text, find, values.

Pandas dataframe#

The data can also be accessed as a pandas dataframe.

>>> df = dataset.get_dataframe()

>>> df.head()
record_number unique_id age birth_day birth_month birth_year gender locality ethnicity religion q1 q2__1
0 2.0 402891.0 22.0 25.0 3.0 1993.0 1.0 1.0 1.0 2.0 4.0 1.0
1 3.0 27541022.0 22.0 27.0 11.0 1993.0 2.0 3.0 1.0 NaN 4.0 0.0
2 4.0 335506.0 28.0 3.0 11.0 1987.0 1.0 2.0 1.0 3.0 7.0 NaN
3 5.0 22885610.0 31.0 11.0 9.0 1984.0 1.0 2.0 1.0 NaN 5.0 NaN
4 6.0 229122.0 38.0 24.0 4.0 1977.0 1.0 1.0 1.0 NaN 2.0 NaN
'
